title: Interpret Slope: Girl to Boy Ratio in Classes
question_text:
A student was interested in the ratio of boys to girls in classes at her school. She randomly selected $10\text{ classes}$ and found the least squares regression line of this data to be $\hat { g } = 23.2-1.7b$, where $b$ is the number of boys in the classroom, and $g$ is the number of girls in the classroom.
Which of the following best describes the meaning of the slope of the least squares regression line?

choices.text: For each additional boy, the estimated number of girls in the classes decreases by $1.7$.
For each additional boy, the estimated number of girls in the classes increases by $23.2$.
For each additional girl, the estimated number of boys in the classes decreases by $1.7$.
For each additional girl, the estimated number of boys in the classes increases by $23.2$.
The slope has no meaning in this case.
